choices.text: Bronchogenic carcinoma with cardiac metastasis

questions.text: A 68-year-old non-smoker presents with dyspnea, chest pain, and pulsus paradoxus. Echocardiogram shows a large pericardial effusion and a right atrial mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiac angiosarcoma

 

Option C:

 

Cardiac angiosarcomas are rare malignant tumors, often arising in the right atrium and presenting with pericardial effusion, tamponade, and bloody fluid. Note that the most common malignant tumour of the heart is Angiosarcoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrial myxoma: More common in the left atrium, less likely to cause bloody effusion.

 

Option B. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Less likely in a non-smoker, and presentation is not typical.

 

Option D. Papillary fibroelastoma: Usually found on heart valves, not associated with pericardial effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac angiosarcomas are rare malignant cardiac tumors that typically arise within the right atrium and are commonly associated with sanguinous pericardial effusion.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with hypertension presents with acute chest pain, unequal blood pressures in the arms, a diastolic murmur, and a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open aortic repair

 

Option C:

 

Diastolic murmur indicates presence of aortic regurgitation which indicates a type A aortic dissection and is a surgical emergency. Open aortic repair is the definitive treatment to prevent aortic rupture and related complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Coronary angiography: Not the priority in this acute setting. CT Angiography would have been more appropriate though.

 

Option B. Intravenous nitroprusside: Used for blood pressure control after the diagnosis is confirmed, but not the definitive treatment.

 

Option D. Thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR): Typically used for uncomplicated type B dissections, not type A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with ascending aortic dissection, immediate open aortic repair is imperative to improve survival and reduce morbidity.

questions.text: A 67-year-old smoker presents with dyspnea, pedal edema and exertional chest pain. He is a known diabetic and hypertensive and on medications for the same. ECG shows LBBB on ECG has an EF of 25% in 2D Echo. What is the most appropriate test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac catheterization

 

Option A:

 

In patients with new-onset heart failure and a high likelihood of CAD, such as this patient with exertional chest pain and LBBB, cardiac catheterization is the most appropriate test to assess for obstructive CAD and guide potential revascularization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cardiac MRI: Can be helpful after CAD is ruled out or for assessing myocardial viability.

 

Option C. Cardiac PET: Can aid in assessing LV function and evaluating for ischemia. However, given this patient's high likelihood of CAD, cardiac catheterization is the most direct and appropriate modality to assess for CAD.

 

Option D. Technetium-99m pyrophosphate scintigraphy: Used for diagnosing transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy, not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with new-onset heart failure and a high likelihood of coronary artery disease should be evaluated with cardiac catheterization.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for sudden-onset dyspnea. Blood pressure is 198/120 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals aortic regurgitation and pulmonary crackles. Emergency chest CT with contrast is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type A aortic dissection

 

Explanation:

 

The most likely diagnosis is type A aortic dissection. The CT scan with contrast shows a dissection plane extending through the aortic arch (arrow). Type A aortic dissection classically presents with the sudden onset of chest or back pain that has a tearing or ripping quality; however, not all patients will have this symptom. Patients may present with hypertension, syncope, a murmur of aortic regurgitation, or heart failure in the setting of sudden aortic insufficiency. The findings of asymmetric blood pressures in the upper extremities, asymmetric pulses, or pulsus paradoxus should all raise suspicion for acute aortic dissection.

choices.text: No splitting with respiration (single)
Persistent inspiratory/expiratory splitting
Splitting in expiration (paradoxic)
Splitting in inspiration (normal)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is evaluated during a routine examination. Blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation is performed with firm pressure on the diaphragm at the upper left sternal border. Which of the following best describes the second sound?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Splitting in inspiration (normal)

 

Explanation:

 

In this patient, auscultation reveals normal splitting of S2 during inspiration. Both components of a split S2 are high-frequency sounds heard best with the diaphragm in the second left intercostal space.

 

Splitting of S2 represents asynchronous closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. In the normal adult, splitting varies with the respiratory cycle and is perceived as a single S2 during expiration and a double S2 during inspiration.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is evaluated for hypotension and orthopnea. The neck veins are examined with the patient in a semirecumbent position. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heart failure

 

Explanation:

 

This patient's neck examination reveals jugular venous distention, reflecting increased right atrial pressure, which is most likely caused by left-sided heart failure. Other causes of jugular venous distension include cardiac tamponade, right ventricular failure, and massive pulmonary embolism.

choices.text: S1 + paradoxical splitting of S2
S1 + physiological splitting of S2

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is evaluated for exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. Blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 60/min. Auscultation over the apical impulse is performed with light pressure on the bell. Which of the following best describes the acoustic events at the apex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) S1 + S2 + S3

 

Explanation:

 

The acoustic events at the apex are best described as S1 + S2 + S3. An S3 is heard in this patient. An S3 is a low-frequency, early diastolic sound best heard with the bell of the stethoscope at the cardiac apex. It may be perceived as a double S2. Positioning the patient in the left lateral decubitus position will facilitate the identification of an S3. An S3 is often heard in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction but can also be present in volume overload states, such as valvular regurgitation, shunt lesions, or late pregnancy. An S3 can also represent a normal finding in children or highly trained athletes.

 

An S4 is also a low-frequency diastolic sound, but it occurs in late diastole and thus may be perceived as a double S1.

 

Both components of a split S2 are high-frequency sounds heard best with the diaphragm in the second left intercostal space. Splitting of the S2 represents asynchronous closure of the aortic and pulmonic valves. In the normal adult, splitting varies with the respiratory cycle and is perceived as a single S2 during expiration and a double S2 during inspiration. Paradoxical splitting of S2 is characterized by audible splitting during expiration and a single S2 during inspiration. It is often associated with aortic stenosis but does not differentiate mild from severe aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is seen on this CT angiogram?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type B aortic dissection

 

Explanation:

 

The CT angiogram shows a Stanford type B aortic dissection arising immediately distal to the take-off of the left subclavian artery and extending to the level of the common iliac arteries. Type B aortic dissections are usually treated with medical therapy that controls blood pressure. β-Blockers are the initial agents of choice. Invasive treatment for type B aortic dissections is reserved for patients with occlusion of a major aortic branch with visceral or limb ischemia, progressive dilation or expansion on medical therapy, or a large penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical manifestations is most likely associated with the findings seen on this CT angiogram?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Livedo reticularis

 

Explanation:

 

The findings seen on this CT angiogram are most likely associated with livedo reticularis. Livedo reticularis is a subtle, lacy network of faintly pink or bluish red vessels, usually seen on the lower legs due to altered blood flow through cutaneous vessels. This CT angiogram shows extensive atherosclerotic disease scattered throughout the central vasculature. Plaques are heavily concentrated in the proximal descending aorta, causing visible narrowing. Aortic atherosclerotic plaques are a significant source of systemic emboli. Emboli from aortic plaques may be thrombotic or atheromatous. Thromboembolism occurs when an atherosclerotic plaque becomes unstable and ruptures, exposing thrombogenic factors that lead to clot formation. Thromboemboli that arise from plaques tend to be single and lodge in small or medium arteries, causing transient ischemic attack, stroke, kidney infarction, intestinal ischemia, or limb ischemia. Atheroemboli result from release of fragments of plaque (such as cholesterol crystals) that tend to lodge more diffusely in smaller arterial beds in different organs; they may result in conditions such as livedo reticularis, “blue toe” syndrome, and retinal or kidney ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the strongest predictor of Cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and subsequent mortality due to CVD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LDL

 

Option C:

 

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol, often referred to as "bad" cholesterol, is the strongest predictor of cardiovascular disease (CVD) incidence and subsequent mortality due to CVD. High levels of LDL cholesterol promote the formation of atherosclerotic plaques in the arteries, leading to narrowing and obstruction of blood flow. This can result in various cardiovascular events, such as heart attacks, strokes, and peripheral artery disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TC/HDL (Total Cholesterol to HDL ratio): While this ratio provides some information about cardiovascular risk, it is not as strong a predictor as LDL cholesterol alone.

 

Option B. hs-CRP (High-sensitivity C-reactive protein): hs-CRP is a marker of inflammation, which can contribute to the development of CVD. However, it is not as directly linked to CVD risk as LDL cholesterol. It has a high negative predictive value with regards to CVD but can be elevated in inflammatory states, hence not very specific.

 

Option D. HDL (High-density lipoprotein cholesterol): Higher levels of HDL are protective, but they are not as strong a predictor of risk as LDL cholesterol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDL cholesterol is the primary target for lipid-lowering therapy in the prevention and management of CVD due to its strong association with CVD incidence and mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following imaging modalities is best for assessing coronary plaque morphology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography)

 

Option B:

 

OCT is considered the best imaging modality for assessing coronary plaque morphology due to its superior resolution compared to other modalities. It provides detailed cross-sectional images of the coronary artery wall, allowing for precise visualization of plaque components such as fibrous cap thickness, lipid core size, and calcification. This information is crucial for determining the vulnerability of plaques and guiding treatment decisions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IVUS (Intravascular Ultrasound): While IVUS provides valuable information about plaque burden and vessel size, its resolution is not as high as OCT, limiting its ability to characterize plaque morphology in detail.

 

Option C. Coronary Angiography: Angiography is a luminal imaging technique that only shows the outline of the vessel lumen. It cannot visualize plaque components within the vessel wall.

 

Option D. CT Coronary Calcium Scoring: This non-invasive technique quantifies the amount of calcium in coronary arteries, a marker of atherosclerosis. However, it does not provide detailed information about plaque morphology or composition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCT is the gold standard imaging modality for assessing coronary plaque morphology due to its superior resolution, which allows for detailed visualization of plaque components and aids in risk assessment and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 68-year-old gentleman is brought into your emergency department after a syncopal episode. ECG shows a regular broad complex tachycardia with no apparent P waves. With regard to the JVP waveform, which of these features would you expect to see?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cannon a waves

 

Option B:

 

The ECG findings suggest either a VT or SVT with aberrancy.

 

  • In VT, the atria and ventricles beat independently of each other (AV dissociation). This leads to occasional coincidental contraction of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve. This results in irregular cannon a waves in the JVP.
  • In SVT with aberrancy atria and ventricles beat together at the same time. This leads to contraction of the right atrium against a closed tricuspid valve with each ventricular beat. This results in regular cannon a waves in the JVP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Giant v waves: Seen in tricuspid regurgitation, not VT.

 

Option C. Prominent x descent: This is a normal finding in the JVP waveform.

 

Option D. Slow y descent: Seen in constrictive pericarditis or cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irregular cannon a waves in the JVP is a sign of AV dissociation, which is commonly seen in ventricular tachycardia and complete

questions.text: An 18-year-old high school student has a syncopal episode while playing basketball. On physical examination, he has a rapid carotid upstroke and a loud systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. ECG and 2D echo showed LVH. What maneuver is expected to decrease the murmur?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hand grip

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation strongly suggests hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The classic findings of a harsh systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, LVH on ECG and echo, and exertional syncope are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Hand grip maneuver: In HCM, increased afterload (e.g., isometric hand grip) reduces the outflow tract obstruction, leading to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Squat-to-stand maneuver: This maneuver increases preload (the volume of blood returning to the heart). In HCM, increased preload can worsen the outflow tract obstruction, leading to an increase in the murmur's intensity.

 

Option C. Valsalva maneuver: This maneuver decreases preload. In HCM, this can initially worsen the outflow tract obstruction, leading to a louder murmur. However, in later phases of the maneuver, the murmur may decrease due to decreased left ventricular volume.

 

Option D. Amyl nitrate inhalation: This maneuver primarily decreases afterload. While it can decrease the intensity of the murmur in HCM, it is not as effective as the hand grip maneuver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCM has a dynamic LVOT obstruction and the murmur correlates with the degree of LVOT obstruction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes for a routine follow-up visit. His physical examination is normal, but an echocardiogram reveals a 1-cm mass attached to the mitral valve with a stalk. The mass is independently mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Papillary fibroelastoma

 

Option D:

 

Papillary fibroelastomas (PFEs) are benign cardiac tumors typically found on valvular surfaces. They are often small, mobile, and attached to the endocardium by a stalk, as described in this patient's echocardiogram.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial endocarditis: Usually presents with fever, chills, and a new or changing murmur.

 

Option B. Left atrial myxoma: Larger and usually attached to the atrial septum, not the valve.

 

Option C. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE): Associated with malignancy or hypercoagulable states, not the typical appearance of PFEs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typical presentation of papillary fibroelastoma on echocardiography → a small, mobile mass attached to a valve by a stalk.

choices.text: Advise the patient that he should not play basketball
Refer for alcohol septal ablation
Refer for implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement

questions.text: An 18-year-old asymptomatic basketball player has come for routine evaluation. On examination he has a brisk carotid upstroke and grade 3/6 systolic murmur in the left sternal border. Echocardiogram showing asymmetric septal hypertrophy (18mm), systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve, and a resting LVOT gradient of 30 mmHg. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise the patient that he should not play basketball

 

Option A:

 

Athletes with a diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) are restricted from most competitive sports due to the high risk of sudden cardiac death during intense exercise.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Beta-blockers: May be used to treat symptoms of HF in HCM, but do not eliminate the risk of sudden cardiac death in athletes.

 

Option C. Alcohol septal ablation: Considered for symptomatic patients with severe LVOT obstruction and have failed initial medical therapy.

 

Option D. ICD placement: Patients with HCM should be considered for implantable cardioverter-defibrillator therapy if they have any of the following risk factors for sudden cardiac death: (1) massive myocardial hypertrophy (wall thickness ≥30 mm), (2) previous cardiac arrest due to ventricular arrhythmia, (3) blunted blood pressure response or hypotension during exercise, (4) unexplained syncope, (5) nonsustained ventricular tachycardia on ambulatory ECG and (6) family history of sudden death due to HCM.

 

An ICD should not be placed solely for the purpose of allowing a patient to participate in high-intensity sports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Athletes with a probable or unequivocal diagnosis of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy may participate in competitive sports that are considered static and low intensity.

choices.text: Routine clinical follow-up without imaging

questions.text: A 48-year-old asymptomatic woman comes for a routine health check-up. On examination she has a grade 2/6 midsystolic murmur localized to the left sternal border that diminishes with standing. Other reports including ECG and chest xray were normal. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Routine clinical follow-up without imaging

 

Option D:

 

Asymptomatic patients with a soft, localized systolic murmur that diminishes with standing most likely have a benign murmur. Additional testing is not necessary in this case, and routine clinical follow-up is sufficient.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac MRI: Unnecessary for an asymptomatic patient with a benign murmur.

 

Option B. TEE: Invasive and not warranted in this scenario.

 

Option C. TTE: Not necessary unless the murmur is associated with other symptoms or abnormalities on physical examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Short, soft systolic murmurs (grade <3) that are well localized to the left sternal border and are not associated with symptoms often do not require further investigation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man with short stature, hypertelorism, and neck webbing has a loud systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border and a click that is heard better with expiration. Which genetic disorder is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Noonan syndrome

 

Option C:

 

The patient's clinical presentation is most consistent with Noonan syndrome, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder with the following characteristics:

 

  • Short stature & facial dysmorphism (Hypertelorism, low-set ears, webbed neck).
  • Cardiac anomalies: The most common cardiac anomaly in Noonan syndrome is pulmonary stenosis which presents with a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and an ejection click that is better heard with expiration. Ejection click of valvular pulmonic stenosis is the ONLY right sided event that is best heard with expiration.
  • Note that Noonan’s syndrome is the most common cause of pulmonic stenosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Down syndrome: More commonly associated with atrioventricular septal defects.

 

Option B. Marfan syndrome: Associated with aortic root dilation and other skeletal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Turner syndrome: Sex chromosome disorder seen in females, not males.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noonan syndrome is commonly associated with congenital cardiac lesions, including pulmonary stenosis.

questions.text: Falsely low BNP (B-type natriuretic peptide) values can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obesity

 

Option B:

 

B-type natriuretic peptide and its N-terminal fraction are increased in heart failure states, and on the population level contribute to prognosis in heart failure states. However, it is important to recognize that natriuretic peptide levels increase with age and renal impairment, are more elevated in women, and can be elevated n right heart failure from any cause. Levels can be falsely low in obese patients. Other biomarkers, such as soluble ST-2 and galectin-3, are newer biomarkers that can be used for determining the prognosis of heart failure patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Advanced age: BNP levels tend to increase with age, so falsely low values are less likely in older individuals.

 

Option C. Female gender: While there may be slight gender differences in BNP levels, it is not a major factor in causing falsely low values.

 

Option D. Smoking: Smoking is not known to significantly affect BNP levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity, constrictive pericarditis, cardiac tamponade and rarely flash pulmonary edema may be associated with lower than expected BNP levels.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following rhythm. His BP is 120/80 mm Hg and his pulse rate is 150/min. The following manoeuvre is performed. What is the manoeuvre?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) REVERT manoeuvre

 

Option B:

 

The REVERT maneuver (modified Valsalva) is a combination of vagal maneuvers used to terminate supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs) like AVNRT. Steps are:

 

  • Have the patient lie semi-recumbent (standard Valsalva).
  • Ask the patient to blow into a 10cc syringe for 15 seconds.
  • Have the patient lie supine with their legs raised to a 45 degree angle for another 15 seconds.
  • Return the patient to the semi-recumbent position.

 

The combined effect of these maneuvers can increase vagal tone, slowing AV nodal conduction and potentially terminating the SVT. In the REVERT trial, 43% patients achieved sinus rhythm with modified Valsalva compared to 17% with the standard Valsalva.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Standard Valsalva: The standard Valsalva manoeuvre alone is less effective than the REVERT manoeuvre in terminating SVTs.

 

Option C. Castell’s manoeuvre: Used fir splenic percussion and not related to cardiology.

 

Option D. Modified squat manoeuvre: There is no such manoeuvre.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REVERT manoeuvre is more effective in terminating paroxysmal SVTs compared to standard Valsalva manoeuvre.

choices.text: Increased sympathetic nervous system activity
Increased parasympathetic nervous system activity

questions.text: A patient with chronic heart failure presents with dyspnea on exertion and fatigue. You ask the patient to do Valsalva and you notice the blood pressure tracing as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired systolic function

 

Option B:

 

The Valsalva maneuver involves forced exhalation against a closed glottis, causing changes in intrathoracic pressure and subsequently affecting cardiac output and blood pressure. A normal response includes a transient decrease in blood pressure during the strain phase followed by an "overshoot" increase upon release, due to increased sympathetic activity and vasoconstriction.

 

In heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), the heart's ability to pump blood effectively is compromised. This impairment of systolic function can lead to blunted baroreceptor reflex and autonomic dysfunction, resulting in a diminished or absent overshoot response during the Valsalva maneuver.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased sympathetic nervous system activity: This would typically lead to an exaggerated overshoot response.

 

Option C. Increased parasympathetic nervous system activity: This would result in a more pronounced decrease in blood pressure during the strain phase but not necessarily affect the overshoot.

 

Option D. Impaired diastolic function: Usually results in a square wave response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the normal physiological response to the Valsalva maneuver and recognize the absence of the overshoot response as a potential sign of impaired systolic function in heart failure.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with dyspnea, fatigue, and peripheral edema. On examination, you observe the JVP as shown in the video and a pansystolic murmur in the left sternal border. This finding is called as:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lancisi sign

 

Option A:

 

The combination of a giant cv wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) coinciding with ventricular systole and a pansystolic murmur at the left sternal border is a classic finding of tricuspid regurgitation (TR). The giant cv wave, also known as Lancisi's sign, is caused by the regurgitant flow of blood from the right ventricle back into the right atrium during systole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bernheim effect: This refers to the displacement of the interventricular septum towards the left ventricle in patients with right ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Muller's sign: This is the systolic pulsation of the uvula seen in severe aortic regurgitation.

 

Option D. Brockenbrough effect: This refers to the paradoxical decrease in pulse pressure in the Post-VPC impulse, seen in HOCM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Lancisi's sign as a clinical manifestation of tricuspid regurgitation, characterized by a giant cv wave in the JVP coinciding with ventricular systole.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with palpitations. You examine his JVP and you see as what is shown in the video below. His pulse rate is 150/min. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventricular tachycardia

 

Option C:

 

The combination of irregular cannon "a" waves in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) and a rapid heart rate strongly suggests ventricular tachycardia (VT).

 

  • Irregular cannon a waves: These occur due to atrioventricular (AV) dissociation, a hallmark of VT. In VT, the atria and ventricles beat independently, causing the atrium to sometimes contract against a closed tricuspid valve, resulting in irregular cannon a waves.
  • Rapid heart rate (150/min): VT is a tachyarrhythmia originating from the ventricles, often presenting with a heart rate above 100 beats per minute.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Complete heart block: This would typically cause bradycardia (slow heart rate) and irregular cannon a waves.

 

Option B. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT): SVTs (like AVNRT) tend to produce regular cannon ‘a’ waves.

 

Option D. WPW syndrome: WPW can cause SVTs (like AVRT) which sometimes can produce regular cannon ‘a’ waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Irregular cannon ‘a’ waves in the JVP is a hallmark of AV dissociation and it is commonly seen in complete heart block and VT.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady presents with ascites, elevated JVP, and pedal edema. Her JVP is shown in the video. All of the following can be the cause except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atrial myxoma

 

Option D:

 

The signs and symptoms presented by the patient (ascites, elevated JVP, pedal edema) are indicative of right heart failure. The JVP is increasing with inspiration and this is called as Kussmaul's sign (seen in conditions that impair right ventricular filling).

 

Atrial myxomas are benign tumors that commonly originate from the left atrium and attached to interatrial septum. Since they arise from left atrium they do not impair RV filling and would not be associated with Kussmaul’s sign.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: The rigid pericardium restricts ventricular filling, leading to right heart failure and Kussmaul's sign. Classic cause of Kussmaul’s sign.

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: The stiff ventricles in this condition also impair filling, causing right heart failure and Kussmaul's sign.

 

Option C. Tricuspid stenosis: This directly obstructs blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle, leading to elevated right atrial pressure, JVP elevation, and Kussmaul's sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kussmaul's sign (increased JVP with inspiration) is a specific finding in conditions that impair right ventricular filling, such as constrictive pericarditis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and tricuspid stenosis.

questions.text: All of the following can cause paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulmonic stenosis

 

Option B:

 

Paradoxical splitting of the second heart sound (S2) occurs when the closure of the pulmonic valve (P2) is heard before the closure of the aortic valve (A2). This is the opposite of normal physiological splitting, where A2 precedes P2. Paradoxical splitting is usually caused by delayed closure of the aortic valve. Pulmonic stenosis does not cause paradoxical splitting. Instead, it causes widened splitting of S2 because the stenosis delays the closure of the pulmonic valve, making the split between A2 and P2 even wider.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. LBBB (Left Bundle Branch Block): Delays left ventricular activation and thus aortic valve closure.

 

Option C. RV pacing: Delays right ventricular activation and thus pulmonic valve closure, leading to A2 preceding P2 on expiration (similar to paradoxical splitting).

 

Option D. HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy): Can cause delayed left ventricular emptying and aortic valve closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic causes of paradoxical splitting are LBBB, severe AS/HOCM and RV pacing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with pounding sensation in the chest for the last 1 hour. On examination you notice the JVP to be elevated and it shown in the video below. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AVNRT (Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia)

 

Option B:

 

Regular cannon "a" waves in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) are most commonly associated with AVNRT. This is because AVNRT involves retrograde conduction of the electrical impulse from the ventricles back to the atria, causing atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ventricular ectopics: Ventricular ectopics can cause irregular cannon a waves but not regular ones.

 

Option C. Tricuspid regurgitation: While tricuspid regurgitation can cause prominent v waves in the JVP, it does not typically cause cannon a waves.

 

Option D. Complete heart block: Complete heart block usually causes irregular cannon a waves due to AV dissociation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the clinical significance of regular cannon a waves in the JVP and their association with AVNRT.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnosis based on the pressure tracing shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HOCM

 

Option B:

 

The pressure tracing shows increase in the LV-Aorta pressure gradient following valsalva and post VPC (called as Brockenbrough effect) which is unique for HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy). Bronckenbrough effect is based on the dynamic LVOT obstruction seen in HOCM.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: Gradient decreases with Valsalva and post VPC.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Does not exhibit bronckenbrough effect.

 

Option D. Aortic regurgitation: Does not exhibit bronckenbrough effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brockenbrough effect is a hallmark of HOCM.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis based on the pulse waveform shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HOCM

 

Option C:

 

The pulse waveform show 2 peaks in systole (pulsus bisferians) with a characteristic spike and dome pattern. It is typical of HOCM (sometimes referred as ‘jerky’ pulse).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ventricular Bigeminy: Associated with pulsus bigeminy.

 

Option B. Aortic Regurgitation: Usually associated with bounding and collapsing (water hammer) pulse. Sometimes can produce pulsus bisferians (in severe cases) but does not have the spike and dome appearance like that of HOCM.

 

 

Option D. Aortic Stenosis: Aortic stenosis typically presents with a slow-rising and delayed pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulsus bisferians can be seen in HOCM, AR and sometimes AS + AR but the spike and dome appearance is typical of HOCM.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of recently diagnosed lymphoma presents with dyspnea and diaphoresis. Blood pressure is 70/60 mm Hg, heart rate is 110 beats/min, and her radial pulse becomes difficult to palpate at times, especially during inspiration. You see the monitor and notice the rhythm as shown in the video. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cardiac tamponade

 

Option D:

 

The combination of hypotension, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus (weakening of the pulse during inspiration), and electrical alternans (beat-to-beat variability in the QRS amplitude) strongly suggests cardiac tamponade. This is a life-threatening condition where fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac compresses the heart, impairing its filling and pumping function.

 

The patient's recent lymphoma diagnosis increases her risk of developing a malignant pericardial effusion, which can rapidly progress to tamponade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute anterior myocardial infarction: While MI can cause hypotension and tachycardia, it is less likely to cause pulsus paradoxus or electrical alternans.

 

Option B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbation: COPD exacerbation can cause dyspnea and tachycardia, but not the other findings in this case.

 

Option C. Myocardial amyloidosis: Amyloidosis can cause restrictive cardiomyopathy, but it is a less likely cause of acute tamponade in this patient with a recent lymphoma diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic clinical presentation of cardiac tamponade is hypotension, tachycardia, pulsus paradoxus, and electrical alternans in ECG.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath. You are attending him and notice the pulse and ECG tracing as shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe LV failure

 

Option A:

 

Pulsus alternans is a physical exam finding characterized by alternating strong and weak pulses. This phenomenon is most commonly associated with severe left ventricular (LV) systolic dysfunction. The weak pulse corresponds to a beat with reduced stroke volume, while the strong pulse represents a beat with a compensatory increase in stroke volume.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade can cause pulsus paradoxus and electrical alternans (not pulsus alternans).

 

Option C. Septic shock: Septic shock usually results in a bounding pulse. Sometimes, it is associated with a. dicrotic pulse.

 

Option D. Digitalis toxicity: Digitalis toxicity causes pulsus bigeminy and not alternans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize pulsus alternans as a clinical sign of severe left ventricular systolic dysfunction and understand its underlying pathophysiology.

choices.text: Diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg
HDL cholesterol level of 30 mg/dL
Total cholesterol level of 250 mg/dL

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, now with a new diagnosis of diabetes mellitus, presents with elevated blood pressure (140/90 mmHg), total cholesterol (250 mg/dL), and hemoglobin A1c (6.6%). Which risk factor confers the highest risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetes mellitus

 

Option A:

 

The factor associated with the highest risk for ASCVD is the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. The presence of diabetes is associated with increased CV risk, particularly among women. Patients with diabetes have a two to four times increased risk for CV disease, with more than two thirds of patients with diabetes eventually dying of heart disease. The risk for stroke is increased 1.8- to 6-fold in patients with diabetes. Additionally, patients with diabetes are more likely to have undiagnosed CAD and have worse outcomes when hospitalized for other CV diseases, such as HF. In this patient, the development of diabetes alone (with all other risk factors held constant) nearly doubled her 10-year risk for ASCVD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B, C, D: A diastolic blood pressure of 90 mm Hg, HDL cholesterol level of 30 mg/dL (0.78 mmol/L) and total cholesterol level of 250 mg/dL (6.47 mmol/L) have a relatively small effect on 10-year ASCVD risk compared with the presence of diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with diabetes mellitus have a 2-4x increased risk for CV disease, with more than two thirds of patients with diabetes eventually dying of heart disease.

choices.text: Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

questions.text: All of the following can produce the murmur depicted in the video except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aortic regurgitation

 

Option B:

 

Aortic regurgitation causes a diastolic murmur due to the backflow of blood from the aorta to the left ventricle during diastole. It is not a continuous murmur.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): This is a persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery, leading to a continuous left-to-right shunt and a continuous "machinery murmur."

 

Option B. Lutemacher syndrome: This is a combination of an atrial septal defect (ASD) and mitral stenosis creating a continuous increase in LA → RA pressure gradient resulting in a continuous murmur.

 

Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm: This can create a fistula between the aorta and right heart chambers, leading to a continuous shunt and murmur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation typically results in an early diastolic murmur.

questions.text: All of the following are causes of a soft first heart sound except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sepsis

 

Option D:

 

Sepsis is a systemic inflammatory response syndrome that often leads to a hyperdynamic state with increased cardiac output. This results in a louder S1 due to more forceful valve closure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calcified valves: Calcification of the mitral valve leaflets can make them rigid and less mobile, leading to a softer S1.

 

Option B. Mitral regurgitation: In some cases of mitral regurgitation, the mitral valve may not close completely, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Option C. Heart failure: Reduced left ventricular contractility in heart failure can lead to less forceful closure of the mitral valve and a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperdynamic states are associated with loud S1.

questions.text: All of the following can result in mid-diastolic murmur except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulmonary regurgitation

 

Option D:

 

Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is associated with early diastolic murmur and not mid-diastolic murmur.  

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Complete heart block: Can result in a mid-diastolic murmur (called Rytand’s murmur)

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Severe aortic regurgitation can cause a mid-diastolic murmur known as the Austin Flint murmur. This occurs due to the regurgitant jet striking the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve, causing it to vibrate and create turbulence.

 

Option C. Acute rheumatic fever: Can result in mitral valvulitis resulting in turbulent blood flow and a mid-diastolic murmur (Carey Coomb’s murmur).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary regurgitation is associated with an early diastolic murmur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old asymptomatic man is found to have a grade II diastolic murmur on routine physical examination. His ECG and chest X-ray are normal. What is the next best step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Echocardiogram

 

Option C:

 

Any diastolic murmur, regardless of intensity, warrants further evaluation to rule out underlying pathology like valvular heart disease. Echocardiography is the most appropriate initial test as it allows for direct visualization of the heart valves and can assess the severity of valvular dysfunction.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cardiac MRI: Offers excellent visualization but is typically reserved for more complex cases or when echocardiography is inconclusive.

 

Option B. Carotid ultrasound: Not relevant for the evaluation of a cardiac murmur.

 

Option C. No further workup: A diastolic murmur always requires further investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A diastolic murmur is always pathological and should be evaluated with echocardiography to assess for underlying structural heart disease.

choices.text: The vertical distance between the top of the jugular venous pulsation and the sternal angle accurately measures central venous pressure (CVP).
The angle of inclination is irrelevant when measuring JVP.
Normally, JVP rises with inspiration due to increased right heart filling.
Venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal.

questions.text: Mr. Tamilvanan, a 67-year-old man, presents with symptoms of heart failure. You are assessing his volume status using JVP examination. Which statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal.

 

Option D:

 

In a normal individual sitting upright, the jugular venous pulsations should not be visible above the clavicle. This is because the right atrium is approximately 10 cm below the clavicle, and any visible pulsations above this level indicate elevated CVP and likely volume overload.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The vertical distance between the top of the JVP and the sternal angle underestimates CVP, and the measurement is affected by body size and patient position.

 

Option B. The angle of inclination is important, as it affects the hydrostatic pressure in the jugular veins.

 

Option C. Normally, the JVP falls with inspiration due to decreased intrathoracic pressure. A rise in JVP with inspiration (Kussmaul's sign) is seen in constrictive pericarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jugular venous pulsations above the clavicle in the sitting position are abnormal and indicative of elevated central venous pressure.

choices.text: SBP increases and DBP decreases when measured in more distal arteries.
SBP in the legs are usually as much as 20 mmHg lower than arm blood pressures.
The difference in blood pressure measured in both arms should be less than 20 mmHg.
Using a BP cuff that is too small will result in a marked underestimation of the true BP.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding blood pressure measurements?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SBP increases and DBP decreases when measured in more distal arteries.

 

Option A:

 

As blood travels further from the heart, the systolic pressure naturally increases due to the reflection of pressure waves from the periphery. At the same time, diastolic pressure decreases due to energy loss in the smaller vessels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Systolic leg blood pressures are actually higher than arm pressures, not lower.

 

Option C. The difference in blood pressure between arms should be less than 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg.

 

Option D. Using a too-small cuff leads to overestimation of blood pressure, not underestimation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

So many things have to be considered while taking BP recordings!

questions.text: What is the cardiac axis marked by ‘?’ in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left Axis

 

Option D:

 

The angles and cardiac axis is depicted in the image below.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right Axis: From +90° to 180°

 

Option B. Northwest Axis: -90° to 180°

 

Option C. Normal Axis: -30° to 90° (or 100°)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Axis determination is important in exams!

questions.text: All of the following diseases are associated with the development of cardiac conduction disease EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperthyroidism

 

Option A:

 

Hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism) causes conduction system abnormalities. Most common conduction system abnormality with hypothyroidism is sinus bradycardia. Several infectious diseases have a predilection for the conducting system. Lyme disease may involve the heart in up to 50% of cases; 10% of patients with Lyme carditis develop atrioventricular (AV) conduction block, which is generally reversible but may require temporary pacing support. Chagas disease, which is common in Latin America, and syphilis, which is common everywhere, may produce more persistent AV conduction disturbances. Some autoimmune and infiltrative diseases may produce AV conduction block, including systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, mixed connective tissue disease, scleroderma, amyloidosis (primary and secondary), sarcoidosis, and hemochromatosis; rare malignancies also may impair AV conduction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lyme disease: Cardiac involvement in Lyme disease can lead to AV block.

 

Option C. Syphilis: This can lead to aortitis and subsequent damage to the conducting system.

 

Option D. Systemic lupus erythematosus: This autoimmune disease can cause inflammation in the heart, including the conduction system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism) causes conduction system abnormalities. Hyperthyroidism is associated with sinus tachycardia and AF.

questions.text: Ms. Anitha, a 24-year-old woman, presents with postural light-headedness and palpitations after a recent upper respiratory illness. Upon standing for 2 minutes, her heart rate increases to 135 beats/min with no change in blood pressure. Which of the following is a reasonable therapeutic option for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sodium chloride tablets

 

Option D:

 

Ms. Anitha's symptoms are consistent with Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS), characterized by an excessive increase in heart rate upon standing, without a significant drop in blood pressure. POTS is often associated with hypovolemia (low blood volume). Increasing sodium intake with sodium chloride tablets can help to increase blood volume, thereby reducing symptoms.

 

POTS is sometimes due to autonomic dysfunction following a viral illness and may resolve spontaneously over 3–12 months. Volume expansion with salt supplementation, oral fludrocortisone, compression stockings, and the α-agonist midodrine, often in combination, can be helpful. Exercise training has also been purported to improve symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluid restriction: This would worsen the hypovolemia and exacerbate the symptoms of POTS.

 

Option B. Upright Yoga: While exercise can be beneficial in the long term, it may initially worsen symptoms in POTS patients due to increased demands on the cardiovascular system.

 

Option C. Furosemide: This is a diuretic that would further decrease blood volume and worsen symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POTS is characterized by symptomatic sinus tachycardia that occurs with postural change from a supine position to standing. The sinus rate increases by 30 beats/min or to >120 beats/min within 10 minutes of standing and in the absence of hypotension.

questions.text: After a common heart transplant operation, a portion of which donor heart chamber will remain in the donor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The most common contemporary cardiac transplant operation is referred to as a “bicaval” orthotopic cardiac transplant that mimics the natural anatomic position. In this operation, the donor and recipient SVC and IVC are connected as are the aortic and pulmonary great vessels. The left atrium of the recipient retains its roof, including the draining pulmonary veins, and the donor left atrium is then sutured to the retained atrial tissue. This technique maintains function of the donor right atrium, which is important for governing early postoperative right heart output, and may prevent atrial arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a standard heart transplantation procedure, the left atrium of the recipient retains its roof, including the draining pulmonary veins, and the donor left atrium is then sutured to the retained atrial tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an early diastolic sound?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) S4

 

Option B:

 

S4 is a late diastolic sound, occurring just before S1, and is associated with atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle. The other options are all early diastolic sounds:

 

  • S3: Occurs early in diastole during rapid ventricular filling, often associated with volume overload or decreased ventricular compliance.
  • OS: High-pitched sound heard shortly after S2, associated with the mitral stenosis.
  • Pericardial knock: Early diastolic sound associated with constrictive pericarditis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. S3: Early diastolic sound.

 

Option C. OS: Early diastolic sound.

 

Option D. Pericardial knock: Early diastolic sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S3, OS, pericardial knock and tumour plop (seen in atrial myxoma) are early diastolic sounds, while S4 is a late diastolic sound.

questions.text:
Mr. Farooq, a 45-year-old man, presents with progressive dyspnea. PFT and CT chest are normal. Echo shows features of pulmonary hypertension and his LVEF is 65%. His cardiac catheterization reports are shown.

 

RA pressure- 10 mmHg

PA pressure - 55/35 (mean = 42) mmHg

PCWP - 34 mmHg

LVEDP - 34 mmHg

Cardiac output - 4.5 L/min

PVR - 1.8 Wood unit

 

What is the most likely cause of his pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HFpEF

 

Option C:

 

Mr. Farooq has normal LV EF (suggesting normal LV systolic function), elevated LVEDP (suggesting diastolic dysfunction), elevated PCWP (suggesting left heart disease) and elevated mean PA pressure (conforming pulmonary hypertension).
Hence Mr. Farooq is likely having a type 2 pulmonary hypertension (due to left heart disease) and other features suggest the likely cause is HFpEF.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic lung disease: Normal PFT and CT chest make chronic lung disease unlikely.

 

Option B. Mitral stenosis: Elevated LVEDP is unlikely in mitral stenosis. Also, mitral stenosis patients have a gradient between LVEDP and PCWP. Identical LVEDP and PCWP rules out mitral stenosis.

 

Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension: The elevated PCWP rules out idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of elevated PCWP equal to LVEDP and normal LV systolic function, consider HFpEF as the cause of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: You are assessing a patient with an aortic aneurysm. You observe hypertelorism, a bifid uvula, and "corkscrew" carotids on imaging. You suspect Loeys-Dietz syndrome. Which protein's gene mutation is responsible for the syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF-β receptor

 

Option D:

 

The findings mentioned in the case are classic features of Loeys-Dietz syndrome which is caused by mutations in the genes encoding transforming growth factor-β receptor 1 (TGFBR1) and 2 (TGFBR2). These mutations lead to increased signaling by TGF-β, which contributes to the development of aortic aneurysms and other characteristic features of the syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator: Mutations in this gene cause cystic fibrosis.

 

Option B. Fibrillin-1: Mutations in this gene cause Marfan syndrome.

 

Option C. STK11 gene: Mutations in this gene cause Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loeys-Dietz syndrome is caused by mutations in the genes encoding TGF-βr.

questions.text: Which of the following rheumatologic diseases is associated with a risk for aortic aneurysms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

Spondyloarthropathies such as ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, relapsing polychondritis, and reactive arthritis (formerly known as Reiter syndrome) are associated with dilation of the ascending aorta. Aortic aneurysms also occur in patients with Behçet syndrome, Cogan syndrome, and IgG4- related systemic disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various rheumatologic diseases have increased risk of aortic aneurysms.

choices.text: Frequent elevation of the lower extremities.

questions.text: All of the following are appropriate therapeutic steps for varicose veins EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aspirin

 

Option A:

 

Varicose veins usually are treated with conservative measures. Symptoms often decrease when the legs are elevated periodically, prolonged standing is avoided, and elastic support hose are worn. External compression with elastic stockings or stretch bandages provides a counterbalance to the hydrostatic pressure in the veins. Although compression garments may improve symptoms, they do not prevent progression of varicose veins. Graduated compression stockings with pressures of 20–30 mmHg are suitable for most patients with simple varicose veins, although pressures of 30–40 mmHg may be required for patients with manifestations of venous insufficiency such as edema and ulcers. Aspirin is not a standard treatment for varicose veins.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Avoid prolonged standing: Prolonged standing increases pressure in the veins of the legs, worsening varicose veins.

 

Option C. Frequent elevation of the lower extremities: Elevating the legs helps reduce pressure in the veins and improves blood flow back to the heart.

 

Option D. Graduated compression stockings: These stockings apply pressure to the legs, helping to improve blood flow and reduce swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is not a standard treatment for varicose veins.

questions.text: All of the following are reasonable therapeutic options for chronic lymphedema EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diuretic therapy

 

Option A:

 

Diuretics are contraindicated in lymphedema as they can deplete intravascular volume and cause metabolic issues. Instead, patients should engage in physical activity and elevate their legs frequently to reduce edema. Psychosocial support is important to address anxiety, depression, and body image issues. Physical therapy, including lymphatic drainage massage and the use of multilayered compressive bandages, can help manage symptoms. After reducing limb volume, patients can use graduated compression hose. Intermittent pneumatic compression devices may also be used at home. In some cases, liposuction with decongestive physiotherapy or microsurgical procedures like lymphatico-venous anastomosis may be considered. However, surgical options are rarely used and often not highly successful.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Frequent leg elevation: Elevating the affected limb helps reduce swelling by promoting lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Intermittent pneumatic compression devices: These devices use air pressure to massage the limb and promote lymphatic flow.

 

Option D. Liposuction: In some cases, liposuction can be used to remove excess fat and reduce the size of the affected limb. Liposuction may be particularly useful in post-mastectomy lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diuretic therapy is ineffective and contraindicated in lymphedema.

choices.text: More men than women suffer from varicose veins.
More men than women suffer from chronic venous insufficiency with edema.
More than 50% of patients over 70 years old have chronic venous insufficiency.
Most patients with chronic venous insufficiency will develop venous ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding chronic venous disease is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) More men than women suffer from chronic venous insufficiency with edema.

 

Option B:

 

Varicose veins are dilated, bulging, tortuous superficial veins, measuring at least 3 mm in diameter. The estimated prevalence of varicose veins is approximately 15% in men and 30% in women. Chronic venous insufficiency is a consequence of incompetent veins in which there is venous hypertension and extravasation of fluid and blood elements into the tissue of the limb. It may occur in patients with varicose veins but usually is caused by disease in the deep veins. Chronic venous insufficiency with edema affects approximately 7.5% of men and 5% of women, and the prevalence increases with age ranging from 2% among those less than 50 years of age to 10% of those 70 years of age. Approximately 20% of patients with chronic venous insufficiency develop venous ulcers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. More men than women suffer from varicose veins: This is incorrect; varicose veins are more common in women.

 

Option C. More than 50% of patients over 70 years old have chronic venous insufficiency: The prevalence in this age group is closer to 10%.

 

Option D. Most patients with chronic venous insufficiency will develop venous ulcers: Only about 20% of patients with chronic venous insufficiency develop venous ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varicose veins are more common in women than in men.

questions.text: In a patient with bacterial endocarditis, which of the following echocardiographic lesions is most likely to lead to embolization?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 11-mm mitral valve vegetation

 

Explanation:

 

Although any valvular vegetation can embolize, vegetations located on the mitral valve and vegetations >10 mm are at greatest risk of embolizing. Of the choices, options B, C, and D are large enough to increase the risk of embolization.

 

Hematogenously seeded infection from an embolized vegetation may involve any organ, but particularly affects those organs with the highest blood flow. They are seen in up to 50% of patients with endocarditis. Tricuspid lesions will lead to pulmonary septic emboli, which is common in injection drug users. Mitral and aortic lesions can lead to embolic infections in the skin, spleen, kidneys, meninges, and skeletal system. A dreaded neurologic complication is mycotic aneurysm, focal dilations of arteries at points in the arterial wall that have been weakened by infection in the vasa vasorum or septic emboli, leading to hemorrhage.

 

Education Objective:

 

Mitral vegetations >10 mm are at greatest risk of embolization
